Modbus Queue
info:
# Modbus Queue

This node queueing read and write messages for modbus. Use this node if you are reading and writing the same device with many different requests. E.g. reading different coil/register intervals continously and also writing to the device at the same time.

It does a few things:
- queues all messages arrive on the input port
- based on the msg.topic, older messages of the same topci is ignored
- sends out the oldest message and waits for the 
- monitors the time since last message and send out report on the output
- handles online/offline status
- resend the last message is response is not received in time

## Input Data

### payload

The payload should contain the data that gets sent to the flex-getter or flex-write node.
Typical modbus read payload:
`{"value":0,"fc":3,"unitid":1,"address":1000,"quantity":20}`
Typical modbus write payload:
`{"value":false,"fc":5,"unitid":1,"address":0,"quantity":1}`

### topic

Each message must contain a topic (any text), and this topic is used to identify the different read/write requests and delete any earlier request with the same topic if it still in the queueing

There are a few reserved topic for special function (for these payload is ignored):
- reset: resets the queue and deleted any data collected so far
- next: this is the message fed back from the flex getter/write node to indicate to this node that a new message can be sent out
- update: this should be coming from a 1 second time to display the current queue count, time since the last update and online/offline status

## Output ports

### Port 1: flex getter

This output should be connected to a modbos-flex-getter and all the read requests will be sent out through this port

### Port 2: flex write

This output should be connected to a modbos-flex-write and all the write requests will be sent out through this port

### Port 3: status messages

This port outputs a status message for every update message (msg.topic="update").

- topic: "Information" for regular updates, "Warning": offline device is now back online, "Error": device is offline
- payload.text: message like when the device gone offline, or back online
- payload.updatetext: time passed since the last update (human readable format)
- payload.secondsincelastupdate: number of seconds since the last update from the device
- payload.statuschange: true if status is changed (gone offline, back online)
- payload.state: 0: initial state, no data yet, 1: device online, 99: device offline

## Node Settings

Change the settings in the first 4 lines of the code to influence the behaviour. Explanation is in the code as comment.

Each message must contain a topic (any text), and this topic is used to identify the different read/write requests and delete any earlier request with the same topic if it still in the queueing

There are a few reserved topic for special function (for these payload is ignored):
- reset: resets the queue and deleted any data collected so far
- next: this is the message fed back from the flex getter/write node to indicate to this node that a new message can be sent out
- update: this should be coming from a 1 second time to display the current queue count, time since the last update and online/offline status

## Output ports

### Port 1: flex getter

This output should be connected to a modbos-flex-getter and all the read requests will be sent out through this port

### Port 2: flex write

This output should be connected to a modbos-flex-write and all the write requests will be sent out through this port

### Port 3: status messages

This port outputs a status message for every update message (msg.topic="update").

- topic: "Information" for regular updates, "Warning": offline device is now back online, "Error": device is offline
- payload.text: message like when the device gone offline, or back online
- payload.updatetext: time passed since the last update (human readable format)
- payload.secondsincelastupdate: number of seconds since the last update from the device
- payload.statuschange: true if status is changed (gone offline, back online)
- payload.state: 0: initial state, no data yet, 1: device online, 99: device offline

## Node Settings

Change the settings in the first 4 lines of the code to influence the behaviour. Explanation is in the code as comment.

name: update log
calc_vol
telemetria
formato_ui
Entrada de Datos y Mantenimiento de Cola
Detección de Estado del Tanque
Manejo de Transiciones de Estado
Cálculo Flujo (Vaciando)
Cálculo Flujo (Rellenando)
func:
const valorFijo = flow.get("valorFijo");
return { payload: valorFijo };

name: Cálculo Flujo (Estable)
Salida de Datos
